comment.author: 35072786@N08
comment._content: pbhome: thank you for the additional information on suffragist Elizabeth Selden Rogers. We will add some of it to our updated description of this image.

comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content: The Wikipedia entry has some misnamed links and other problems. It would seem that this is Mrs. John Rogers, Sr. and that John, Jr. was their young son. It doesn't help that they named their children, a boy and a girl, after themselves. Though perhaps the caption is correct. The New York Times and another source also refer to her by the captioned name. It seems that though her husband was the son of a John Rogers himself, their son was also called John Rogers, Jr. They seem to be standing on this vehicle, pictured elsewhere in the Bain collection, which I believe was called the Suffrage Van: lcweb2.loc.gov/service/pnp/ggbain/18900/18951v.jpg ></a

comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content: Similar Women's Political Union banner in this photo:

comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content: A similar photo of the W.P.U. Suffrage Van made the front page of the New York Herald's May Day edition in 1915. fultonhistory.com/Newspaper%2014/New%20York%20NY%20Evenin... The motivation behind the Suffrage Van (roving speaker's platform and shop) is explained in this contemporary account (N.Y. Herald, April 25, 1915) fultonhistory.com/Newspaper%2014/New%20York%20NY%20Herald...

comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content: I think I now have this straightened out, and I'm fixing her Wikipedia entry as well. She is incorrectly identified here as Mrs. John Rogers, Jr. , though Bain and the New York Times referred to her that way. Here is her entry in Woman's Who's Who of America (1914): "ROGERS, Elizabeth Selden White, (Mrs. John Rogers), 102 East 80th St NY City Born Astoria LI July 23 1868, dau Charles Atwood and Frances Spencer (Eaton) White Ed private school New Haven Conn, Miss Porter's School Farmlngton Conn m[arried] New Haven Conn Nov 27 1895 Dr John Rogers children John Rogers Jr, Charles White died 1903, Elizabeth Selden, Mem[ber] Conn Soc Colonial Dames of sciences Mem Conn Soc Colonial Dames of America Mem Exec Board Women's Political Union NY City" books.google.com/books?id=COsLAAAAIAAJ&q=rogers#v=sni... She was also one of the "Silent Sentinels", arrested and jailed for picketing the White House for women's suffrage at a Bastille Day demonstration by the National Women's Party on July 14, 1917. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Silent_Sentinels lcweb2.loc.gov/ammem/collections/suffrage/nwp/tactics.pdf

comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content: I have now made some corrections and additions to her Wikipedia entry. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elizabeth_Selden_Rogers
